94256F717BD34D2EB4CDF603AA155DFC.description:
Design and test possible devices or solutions that reduce the effects of friction on the
motion of an object.

3A3CF2FA580E43FD9BAD146E89AF9AF8.description:
Analyze and interpret data to describe how a change of force, a change in mass, or
friction affects the motion of an object.

FD6D491CE8184318A5CCF3B13AE24A18.description:
Plan and conduct controlled scientific investigations to test the effects of balanced and
unbalanced forces on the rate and direction of motion of objects.

7881B9A64B7F4632992C2D51C3B11BF7.description: Develop and use models to explain how the amount or type of force (contact and noncontact) affects the motion of an object.

0C678F9736F84B46991AD1FCB2B865AB.description:
Use mathematical and computational thinking to describe and predict the motion of an
object (including position, direction, and speed).

99FE0CCFBE2A4BBB8DB8BF1B6CCFAD77.description:
The motion of an object can be described in terms of its
position, direction, and speed. The rate and motion of an object is determined by multiple factors.

EC588AF46EBF46F79066D8D0C4A18B28.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of the factors that affect the motion
of an object.

84A86F82225B496199DEEDFA21A76AF7.description:
Construct scientific arguments to explain how limiting factors (including food, water,
space, and shelter) or a newly introduced organism can affect an ecosystem.

6B987FB29C634CA795F86C3F4EA3E29D.description:
Construct explanations for how organisms interact with each other in an ecosystem
(including predators and prey, and parasites and hosts).

99E1CDFA5BA549A5BCB3791425F04D3A.description:
Develop and use models of food chains and food webs to describe the flow of energy in
an ecosystem.

B330A49CF98749A1A65FEAC7CD4320B5.description:
Analyze and interpret data to explain how organisms obtain their energy and classify an
organisms as producers, consumers (including herbivore, carnivore, and omnivore), or
decomposers (such as fungi and bacteria).

2E7D03527D0349F38907D739B1E85358.description:
All organisms need energy to live and grow. Energy is
obtained from food. The role an organism serves in an ecosystem can be described by the way in
which it gets its energy. Energy is transferred within an ecosystem as organisms produce, consume,
or decompose food. A healthy ecosystem is one in which a diversity of life forms are able to meet
their needs in a relatively stable web of life.

818D7F5D97B143AB89A545525D0D23EF.description:
Obtain and communicate information to describe and compare the biotic factors
(including individual organisms, populations, and communities) of different terrestrial
and aquatic ecosystems.

4CB27851EF484636BDF00F249EB3E4BC.description:
Analyze and interpret data to summarize the abiotic factors (including quantity of light
and water, range of temperature, salinity, and soil composition) of different terrestrial
ecosystems and aquatic ecosystems.

A8CCDD9957624B5F8E7210D460820B59.description:
Ecosystems are complex, interactive systems that include
both the living components (biotic factors) and physical components (abiotic factors) of the
environment. Ecosystems can be classified as either terrestrial (such as forests, wetlands, and
grasslands) or aquatic (such as oceans, estuaries, lakes, and ponds).

F4054A3FA16140CF8E16517B9206D7EE.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of relationships among biotic and
abiotic factors within terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems.

500CC353EEDE4DDB979134F503FB59A0.description: Life Science: Interdependent Relationships in Ecosystems

B7F7B281AE8B4E53928145050A85CC75.description:
Define problems caused by natural processes or human activities and test possible
solutions to reduce the impact on landforms and the ocean shore zone.

CD2A69DDD174483CA1E12315A5B9374A.description:
Construct scientific arguments to support claims that human activities (such as
conservation efforts or pollution) affect the land and oceans of Earth.

971D6813AD154CD2B9006DFD454F683E.description:
Develop and use models to explain the effect of the movement of ocean water (including
waves, currents, and tides) on the ocean shore zone (including beaches, barrier islands,
estuaries, and inlets).

264820DE47664E4EA61B914E5478E9C0.description:
Analyze and interpret data to describe and predict how natural processes (such as
weathering, erosion, deposition, earthquakes, tsunamis, hurricanes, or storms) affect
Earth’s surface.

36812972FBD14996BE5074125561E2AA.description:
Earth’s oceans and landforms can be affected by natural
processes in various ways. Humans cannot eliminate natural hazards caused by these processes but
can take steps to reduce their impacts. Human activities can affect the land and oceans in positive
and negative ways.

8D97B3910458444E9E150D29003E5DDA.description:
Develop and use models to describe and compare the characteristics and locations of the
landforms on continents with those on the ocean floor (including the continental shelf
and slope, the mid-ocean ridge, the rift zone, the trench, and the abyssal plain).

BFEE2651EDA74C3DA388493E3151FE4B.description:
Construct explanations of how different landforms and surface features result from the
location and movement of water on Earth’s surface through watersheds (drainage basins)
and rivers.

6C8A3E50318C4C2897A9B4974376F3DD.description:
Some of the land on Earth is located above water and some is
located below the oceans. The downhill movement of water as it flows to the ocean shapes the
appearance of the land. There are patterns in the location and structure of landforms found on the
continents and those found on the ocean floor.

B16AD16EBC0E4514BD28A598A105A8B4.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of how natural processes and
human activities affect the features of Earth’s landforms and oceans.

D270F3B526AC436A8157349BE9B041DC.description: Earth Science: Changes in Landforms and Oceans

962D26C7F9084F3EA22B59D5C1A008AD.description:
Design and test the appropriate method(s) (such as filtration, sifting, attraction to
magnets, evaporation, chromatography, or floatation) for separating various mixtures.

0205D89FC2BD48D68494563A4BAC2997.description:
Conduct controlled scientific investigations to test how different variables (including
temperature change, particle size, and stirring) affect the rate of dissolving.

2AE6A10523FB48A1B4AAE2F625ACDA63.description:
Construct explanations for how the amount of solute and the solvent determine the
concentration of a solution.

D8A00F23EFEC4181A73A95796425AA5F.description:
Develop models using observations to describe mixtures, including solutions, based on
their characteristics.

E36F7A75A5244F5E8B3198FC6C481F81.description:
Analyze and interpret data to support claims that when two substances are mixed the
total amount (mass) of the substances does not change.

DA17611C3FF342409995429B81497062.description:
Obtain and communicate information to describe what happens to the properties of
substances when two or more substances are mixed together.

91FB880589164DC9A1BAB02057E715EE.description:
A mixture is formed when two or more kinds of matter are
put together. Sometimes when two or more different substances are mixed together, a new
substance with different properties may be formed but the total amount (mass) of the substances is
conserved. Solutions are a special type of mixture in which one substance is dissolved evenly into
another substance. When the physical properties of the components in a mixture are not changed,
they can be separated in different physical ways.

41ACECF5DD0E4528AAFA068A287B4F9C.description:
Analyze and interpret data from observations and measurements of the physical
properties of matter (including volume, shape, movement, and spacing of particles) to
explain why matter can be classified as a solid, liquid or gas.

AADECB070CA7456F9BF0CC258A47A96C.description:
Matter is made up of particles that are too small to be seen.
Even though the particles are very small, the movement and spacing of these particles determines
the basic properties of matter.

0FAC0A37F45C4B81BBE7362FF3CC4034.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of the physical properties of matter
and mixtures.

76AD2E4070054D929C76688BD0D39C63.description:
Construct devices or design solutions to solve specific problems or needs: (1) ask
questions to identify problems or needs, (2) ask questions about the criteria and
constraints of the devices or solutions, (3) generate and communicate ideas for possible
devices or solutions, (4) build and test devices or solutions, (5) determine if the devices
or solutions solved the problem and refine the design if needed, and (6) communicate the
results.

7C698C60027B40D49CB74FA1E0A7A4B6.description:
Technology is any modification to the natural world created
to fulfill the wants and needs of humans. The engineering design process involves a series of
iterative steps used to solve a problem and often leads to the development of a new or improved
technology.

52EE1D1653184624A4E994BA04BB5C32.description:
Obtain and evaluate informational texts, observations, data collected, or discussions to
(1) generate and answer questions, (2) understand phenomena, (3) develop models, or
(4) support hypotheses, explanations, claims, or designs. Communicate observations and
explanations using the conventions and expectations of oral and written language.

4FC2ACFA69E144B7A9CB42214B7CCFF0.description:
Construct scientific arguments to support claims, explanations, or designs using
evidence from observations, data, or informational texts.

0C74DDBB2EE24C59B94635F598E8712A.description:
Construct explanations of phenomena using (1) scientific evidence and models,
(2) conclusions from scientific investigations, (3) predictions based on observations and
measurements, or (4) data communicated in graphs, tables, or diagrams.

D96EC5EEBCDD47AFA87BB13AD75CEBB9.description:
Analyze and interpret data from informational texts, observations, measurements, or
investigations using a range of methods (such as tabulation or graphing) to (1) reveal
patterns and construct meaning or (2) support hypotheses, explanations, claims, or
designs.

99DAA837F075420F84D5FFC3D88A96AC.description:
Plan and conduct controlled scientific investigations to answer questions, test hypotheses
and predictions, and develop explanations: (1) formulate scientific questions and testable
hypotheses, (2) identify materials, procedures, and variables, (3) select and use
appropriate tools or instruments to collect qualitative and quantitative data, and
(4) record and represent data in an appropriate form. Use appropriate safety procedures.

CCB9B146707A43AD945304C82B9311D4.description:
Develop, use, and refine models to (1) understand or represent phenomena, processes,
and relationships, (2) test devices or solutions, or (3) communicate ideas to others

FE02B12F81BA432EA0998D84409263DC.description:
Ask questions used to (1) generate hypotheses for scientific investigations or (2) refine
models, explanations, or designs.

C0003F3D3A824D5BBC1734BBF91EF932.description:
The practices of science and engineering support the
development of science concepts, develop the habits of mind that are necessary for scientific
thinking, and allow students to engage in science in ways that are similar to those used by scientists
and engineers.

173EB6D773514B479F64C107446561B9.description:
The student will use the science and engineering practices, including the processes
and skills of scientific inquiry, to develop understandings of science content.
